client.name: African American Museum
client.description: Client had existing building needing major renovation

client_screening.screened_out_reason: Massive budget/scope mismatch - claimed $500K budget but building needed roof, HVAC, ADA compliance PLUS complete museum exhibits. Client ignored reality when told budget was insufficient.

scope.primary_deliverable: Complete exhibition design for indoor museum

space_description.description: Upper and lower levels, existing building requiring major infrastructure work

renderings.shows: MLK imagery, African diaspora maps, portrait towers

design_features: Wood paneling with indirect cove lighting

methodology.notes: NO methodology, budget details, personas, research, timeline, or evaluation framework. Visual-focused exhibition design only.

budget_realism_check.notes: MAJOR RED FLAG: Client claimed $500K budget but building needed roof, HVAC, ADA compliance PLUS complete museum exhibits with media studio, maker space, events space. Budget completely insufficient for scope.

project_financials.notes: Pro bono work for portfolio despite client's unrealistic expectations

what_didnt_work: Client with building but insufficient budget for both infrastructure and exhibits
When budget is 1/4 of what's needed, project won't happen
Multiple follow-up attempts failed - client disappeared
Pro bono work doesn't guarantee client commitment
lessons_learned.budget_reality_check: $500K claimed vs $2M+ needed (roof, HVAC, ADA, exhibits) = impossible

follow_up_strategy.notes: Attempted multiple follow-ups, no response from client

public_presentation.strategic_value: Portfolio piece demonstrating exhibition design capability

ai_training_quality.notes: Good example of budget red flag pattern - massive scope/budget mismatch

notes: Pro bono portfolio piece that failed due to catastrophic budget/scope mismatch. Client had building needing major infrastructure work (roof, HVAC, ADA compliance) PLUS wanted complete museum with exhibits, media studio, maker space, events space for $500K. Realistic budget would have been $2M+. Client ignored reality when told, then disappeared despite multiple follow-up attempts. Excellent example of red flag: when client's budget is 1/4 of what's actually needed.

project_name: Arizona Mining, Mineral, and Natural Resources Education Museum (AMMNREM)

client.name: University of Arizona
client.description: Former Arizona Mining and Mineral Museum building (Polly Rosenbaum Building). $12M appropriated by Arizona Senate for building repairs.

demographics.metro_area: Phoenix metropolitan area (5th largest in US)

primary_contact.name: Dr. Elliott Cheu
primary_contact.title: Ph.D., Associate Vice President, University Research Institutes Research
primary_contact.notes: STRATEGIC CONTACT - dean with actual authority, not inexperienced ED

if_rfp.rfp_issuer: Arizona Mining, Mineral, and Natural Resources Museum Advisory Committee

documents.notes: Project scope document - 4 phases, workshops, deliverables list
Budget spreadsheet showing bidding strategy: $96K → $86K (20% discount) → $67K (strategic underbid)
Contract letter to Dr. Elliott Cheu confirming $67,180 fee

scope.primary_deliverable: Master Plan / Museum Planning / Schematic Exhibition Design

space_description.building_type: Historic Polly Rosenbaum Building, former Arizona Mining and Mineral Museum
space_description.location_context: Downtown Phoenix, adjacent to state capitol, near African American community
space_description.description: 1502 West Washington Street - historic building with $12M state appropriation for repairs

budget.notes: $12M appropriated by Arizona Senate via State Bill 1415 for building repairs

project_financials.underbid_rationale: BIDDING STRATEGY DOCUMENTED: Started at $96K → 20% discount to $86K → Final strategic bid $67K to win competitive RFP and be 'least expensive bidder'
comparable_benchmarks: Cranbrook Strategic Plan ($96K - similar scope without underbid)
McDonough Cultural Plan ($35K - smaller citywide scope)
project_financials.notes: COMPLETE BIDDING DOCUMENTATION: Excel shows $96,300 original → $86,300 with 20% discount → Final contract $67,180. Strategic 30% underbid to win. Worth $130K+ but bid $67K to be least expensive and build university relationship.

client_financial_profile.notes: $12M appropriated via state legislation - strong funding. University has internal PDC Design/Build team for implementation.

what_worked: Strategic underbid won competitive RFP ($67K vs $96K original)
what_didnt_work: $400M university overspending scandal killed all projects
Even perfect funding can be destroyed by external scandal

ai_training_quality.notes: EXCELLENT: Complete bidding documentation shows $96K → $86K → $67K strategy. Contract letter, budget spreadsheet, scope document, final plan all present.

project_name: Arizona Natural Resources Museum (ANRM) Master Plan

client.name: University of Arizona
client.building_description: Former Arizona Mining and Mineral Museum

primary_contact.name: Executive Director (African American woman, no museum/fundraising background)
primary_contact.title: Executive Director
primary_contact.notes: Inexperienced - no museum or fundraising background, hired by university

better_contact.name: Elliott Cheu
better_contact.title: Dean
better_contact.notes: Strategic dean who actually makes decisions - better follow-up contact

client_screening.notes: Qualified client type (university) but project killed by institutional scandal

space_description.building_type: Historic former Mining and Mineral Museum
space_description.location_context: Adjacent to African American community and downtown/state buildings

methodology.approach_emphasis: Financial sustainability, low capital costs, rapid implementation

partner_organizations.role: Key stakeholder - building adjacent to community

project_financials.underbid_rationale: Strategic underbid to win competitive RFP, build university relationship, was least expensive bidder
project_financials.notes: Won competitive RFP despite being least expensive - work worth $130K+

external_pressure.description: State Bill 1415 appropriated $12M, State Representative Gail Griffin involved, community engagement documented

political_context.political_agenda: State Senator offered University $12M to reopen as mining museum, pivoted to Natural Resources after community pushback
political_context.notes: African American community didn't want mining museum. University $400M overspending scandal froze everything.

threats: Scope creep requests for free consulting

what_worked: Competitive RFP won with strategic underbid
what_didnt_work: University scandal can kill even well-funded projects
Inexperienced ED is major risk
Scope creep attempts post-contract
would_do_differently: Contact Elliott Cheu (strategic dean) not inexperienced ED for follow-up

primary_contact.name: Elliott Cheu
primary_contact.title: Dean
primary_contact.why: Strategic dean who actually makes decisions - avoid inexperienced ED who kept asking for free consulting

avoid_contacting.name: Executive Director
avoid_contacting.reason: Inexperienced, no museum/fundraising background, scope creep requests for free work

comparable_projects.similarity: Benchmarked against Flandrau Science Center Tucson in master plan

public_presentation.notes: In limbo due to university scandal

ai_training_quality.notes: Excellent example of external pressure (state legislation) + institutional scandal kill shot

notes: Had all success indicators: State Bill 1415 with $12M appropriation, State Representative involvement, University backing, community engagement, historic preservation angle. Mark strategically underbid ($67K for $130K+ value) to win competitive RFP. KILL SHOT: University $400M overspending scandal froze all projects. Inexperienced ED (no museum/fundraising background) couldn't move forward, kept asking Mark for free consulting. LESSON: Contact Elliott Cheu (strategic dean) for follow-up, not the inexperienced ED. Shows even well-funded, politically-backed projects can be killed by institutional crisis.

location.address: McDonough Square, 34 John Frank Ward Blvd

primary_contact.name: City Manager
primary_contact.title: City Manager
primary_contact.notes: BEST CLIENT TYPE - City Manager with mandate from Mayor/Council

political_champion.name: Mayor Billy Copeland
political_champion.title: Mayor
political_champion.role: Retiring after 50 years - wanted legacy museum
political_champion.authority: Handed to City Manager with 'just do it' mandate

decision_speed_indicator.notes: 15-minute meeting with Mayor - pointed at rendering, said 'I want that', handshake, done

related_documents.relationship: Museum reopening inspired citywide 5-year cultural master plan

scope.primary_deliverable: Fabrication drawings for interactive museum exhibits

target_audience.age_range: All ages, focus on families and kids

educational_programming.philosophy: No electronics in Kid's Area to develop imaginations

budget.notes: Total project budget not specified in fabrication drawings

project_financials.notes: $300,000 across all phases (proposal → design → fabrication → implementation)
project_financials.funding_context: $1 BILLION in SPLOST funds available to city

external_pressure.description: Mayor Copeland retiring after 50 years wanted legacy museum. Post office had leaking roof, holes in floor, WPA mural needing preservation.

funding_status.source: SPLOST (Special Purpose Local Option Sales Tax)
funding_status.notes: $1 BILLION in SPLOST funds available - money not an issue

political_context.political_champion: Mayor Billy Copeland (50 years in office, retiring)

decision_speed.timeline: 15-minute meeting, Mayor pointed at rendering, said 'I want that', handshake, done

success_formula.pattern: Political deadline (retiring mayor) + Authority structure (City Manager with mandate) + Money already appropriated (SPLOST) + Real estate driver (historic WPA mural) + Fast decision (15-minute meeting, immediate yes) = PROJECT GETS BUILT

lifecycle_phases.description: New Mayor Sandra Vincent (Black) found museum 'racist' (vanity project for white retiring mayor in diverse community)

lifecycle_phases.reason: Election pressure - bad optics to keep closed. Mayor contacted Mark, he reopened most of museum within days

lifecycle_phases.status: Closed again after mayor lost election

lifecycle_phases.outcome: Museum reopening inspired citywide Cultural Plan 2026-2031

threats: Cultural sensitivity - vanity project for white mayor in diverse community

expansion_opportunity.catalyst: Museum reopening success inspired Mayor Vincent to commission 5-year cultural master plan

what_worked: City Manager as client = best decision maker type
15-minute meeting with fast yes = strong signal
SPLOST funding = money already there, not fundraising
Lead with renderings for fast-decision clients
what_didnt_work: Political vulnerability to new administration
Cultural sensitivity in diverse community
Museum as political legacy can become target
lessons_learned.replicable_model: This is the McDonough Formula: Fast decision + Appropriated funding + Political deadline + City Manager authority = Success

comparable_projects.comparison_notes: Discovery Center failed with Director of Development vs C.O. Polk succeeded with City Manager

public_presentation.marketed_as: Built and operational (complexity of political situation not detailed)

ai_training_quality.notes: PERFECT example of success formula - all data complete, video documentation, full lifecycle tracked

notes: THE SUCCESS FORMULA PROJECT: Mayor retiring (50 years) = deadline pressure. Handed to City Manager = best client type. $1B SPLOST available = money not issue. 15-minute meeting, Mayor points at rendering 'I want that' = fast decision signal. Historic WPA mural = preservation mandate. Project built and opened 2020. COVID + new mayor (Sandra Vincent) closed it calling it 'racist' vanity project. Election pressure forced reopening 2024, Mark got it operational in days. Mayor lost reelection, museum closed again. BUT: Success of reopening inspired Mayor Vincent to commission citywide Cultural Plan 2026-2031 ($35K fee, worth $100K+). Museum project expanded to citywide cultural infrastructure planning. REPLICABLE MODEL.

project_name: Cranbrook Institute of Science Strategic Plan 2027-2029

client.name: Cranbrook Institute of Science (part of Cranbrook Educational Community)
client.description: Major science museum, part of Cranbrook Educational Community (CEC). Following nearly 3 decades of consistent leadership, entering pivotal new era under Lucy Hale, Susan Flint Cooper Director.

primary_contact.name: Lucy Hale
primary_contact.title: The Susan Flint Cooper Director
primary_contact.notes: New director after 30 years of previous leadership - modernization opportunity

decision_speed_indicator.notes: RFP issued Nov 3, proposals due Nov 14, award by Nov 19, contract Nov 21 - VERY FAST 18-day cycle

if_rfp.stated_scope: Strategic plan 2027-2029, in-person workshops, 3-year working plan by Sept 2026

documents.file_path: /tmp/Proposal – Strategic Planning Services for Cranbrook Institute of Science (2027–2029) v2.pdf

documents.notes: Detailed budget spreadsheet - $92K version (final proposal was $96.2K)

scope.primary_deliverable: 3-year Strategic Plan (2027-2029) for major science museum

space_description.description: Cranbrook Institute of Science, part of Cranbrook Educational Community (CEC), modernization and expansion focus

focus_areas: Board and CEC Strategic Framework alignment

methodology.approach_emphasis: Inclusive, measurable, forward-looking planning. Collaborative and data-driven. Translates vision into action.

methodology_documented.framework_name: 6-Phase Strategic Planning Framework for Science Museums

pillars.name: Marketing, Audience Engagement & Campus Relationships
pillars.description: Expand regional reach and visitor experience

pillars.name: Education and Community Impact
pillars.description: STEAM education and environmental literacy leadership

pillars.name: Board and CEC Alignment
pillars.description: Align with Cranbrook Educational Community Strategic Framework

kpis.description: Clear metrics for each strategic pillar

deliverables: Director Vision Summary (10 pages with visuals)
Departmental Findings Report across 5 focus areas

budget_realism_check.notes: $96,200 for comprehensive 9-month, 6-phase strategic plan with stakeholder engagement, benchmarking, Board workshops - appropriate for major science museum. Includes all travel.

cost_per_sqft.based_on: Strategic planning, not construction - cost/sqft not applicable

comparable_benchmarks: McDonough Cultural Plan ($35K for citywide - smaller scope)
ANRM Master Plan ($67K fee - similar scope, strategic underbid)
Discovery Center Strategic Plan ($1M+ total project budget)
project_financials.strategic_value: Major established science museum (1904) strategic planning demonstrates high-value capability with prestigious institutions
project_financials.notes: $96,200 proposal (final). Excel budget showed $92K. 2-payment structure: 50% at contract signing, 50% at completion. Contract Nov 21, 2025 if awarded.

client_financial_profile.notes: Cranbrook Educational Community - prestigious, well-established (1904). Planning capital and endowment campaign, deferred maintenance funding. Strong financial position indicated.

external_pressure.description: New director (Lucy Hale) after 30 years of previous leadership = unique modernization opportunity. Board-driven strategic planning for 2027-2029. Capital campaign preparation creates urgency.

funding_status.source: Museum operating budget / strategic planning allocation
funding_status.notes: RFP with 18-day turnaround (Nov 3 → Nov 21) indicates budget already committed and Board approval secured

political_context.political_champion: Lucy Hale (new director) + Board of Governors
political_context.political_agenda: Modernization after 30 years, capital campaign, facilities improvement, CEC alignment
political_context.notes: Leadership transition = opportunity. Fast RFP timeline = Board alignment and commitment. Aligning with CEC Strategic Framework.

decision_speed.fast_decision_signal: VERY STRONG - fastest RFP cycle in database (18 days total). Indicates urgency, commitment, Board pre-approval.

workforce_development_project.notes: Strategic planning for established science museum. STEAM education focus but not workforce development per se.

educational_integration.notes: STEAM education and environmental literacy are core strategic focus areas

what_worked: 18-day RFP cycle = strong success signal (fastest in database)
Capital campaign preparation = external forcing function
Clear RFP scope = no scope creep risk
lessons_learned.notes: Proposal stage - outcome pending Nov 19, 2025 decision

comparable_projects.comparison_notes: Discovery Center failed with Director of Development. Cranbrook has Executive Director with Board backing.
ANRM was $67K (underbid), had $12M appropriated. Cranbrook is $96K for strategic planning only.

public_presentation.strategic_value: Major science museum (founded 1904, Cranbrook) strategic planning demonstrates capability with prestigious, established institutions. Portfolio value significant.

ai_training_quality.notes: EXCELLENT data: Complete RFP + Proposal + Budget spreadsheet. Fast decision timeline (18 days). Clear scope. Prestigious client. Outcome pending but strong success indicators.

notes: Cranbrook Institute of Science Strategic Plan 2027-2029. FASTEST RFP CYCLE IN DATABASE: 18 days (Nov 3 RFP → Nov 14 deadline → Nov 19 award → Nov 21 contract). $96,200 fee for 9-month, 6-phase strategic planning (Jan-Sep 2026). Prestigious client: Founded 1904, part of Cranbrook Educational Community. NEW DIRECTOR after 30 years = modernization opportunity. Lucy Hale (Susan Flint Cooper Director) leading. 5 strategic focus areas: Marketing/Audience, Fundraising, Education/STEAM, Facilities, Board/CEC alignment. Preparing for capital and endowment campaign. Board of Governors engagement throughout. Payment: 50% at signing, 50% at completion. References provided: Elliott Cheu (ANRM Arizona), Mayor Copeland (McDonough), Jon-Paul Dyson (Strong Museum). Fast timeline indicates Board pre-approval and budget committed. Strong success probability. Proposal submitted Nov 13, 2025. Outcome pending Nov 19 decision.

project_name: Discovery Center at Murfree Spring - Nature Play Strategic Plan

client.name: Discovery Center
client.description: 30,000 square feet post-2007 expansion (18,000 prior). Existing children's science museum with unused back area for outdoor nature playground.

demographics.tourism_notes: Part of Nashville metro tourism market

primary_contact.title: Director of Development
primary_contact.notes: CRITICAL RED FLAG: Director of Development leading instead of ED/Board - pattern almost always fails

decision_speed_indicator.notes: No decision made after comprehensive 86-page strategic plan delivered

client_screening.screened_out_reason: Director of Development led (almost always difficult per Mark), no clear funding commitment, donor 'contact' not actual commitment, no follow-up after submission - classic failure pattern

scope.primary_deliverable: Strategic plan for outdoor nature play science playground

space_description.building_type: Outdoor science playground addition to existing 30K sqft children's museum
space_description.location_context: Unused back area of existing children's science museum
space_description.description: Museum is 30,000 sqft post-2007 expansion (18,000 prior to expansion). Project focuses on outdoor addition.

methodology_documented.framework_name: Comprehensive strategic planning with personas, empathy maps, journey maps, and evaluation framework

technology.description: 3 solar-powered pop-up museums for outdoor nature interpretation
Mobile application for visitor engagement and wayfinding

breakdown_by_year.phase: Major infrastructure - Nature Pods and construction

breakdown_by_category.description: Major technology investment for outdoor interpretation

budget_realism_check.notes: $1,021,000 over 6 years for outdoor science playground - appropriately phased with largest investment (62%) in year 2 for infrastructure. Budget is realistic for scope.

deliverables: Strategic plan with detailed timeline and evaluation framework

cost_per_sqft.based_on: Cannot calculate - outdoor addition to existing 30K sqft facility, project sqft not specified

project_financials.notes: Paid project but fee amount not disclosed in conversation. Total project budget $1,021,000.

client_financial_profile.notes: Budget appears appropriate for scope, problem was lack of funding commitment not budget amount

external_pressure.description: No political deadline, no grant deadline, no external forcing function - project could drag indefinitely

funding_status.notes: Director of Development had donor 'contact' interested in funding - RED FLAG: contact ≠ commitment. No actual funding secured.

workforce_development_project.notes: Outdoor nature play focus, not interactive STEAM for economic development

what_didnt_work: Director of Development as project lead (Mark: 'almost always difficult')
Donor 'contact' vs actual funding commitment - huge difference
No external pressure to force decision (no deadline, no political champion)
Projects without forcing functions often die even with good plans
Comprehensive 86-page strategic plan doesn't matter if wrong decision maker
lessons_learned.template_value: Excellent example of what NOT to do - shows importance of decision maker type and funding commitment vs hoping

avoid_contacting.name: Director of Development
avoid_contacting.reason: Never heard back after comprehensive strategic plan submission, no funding commitment materialized, pattern indicates unlikely to close

comparable_projects.similarity: Outdoor/interactive components, STEAM education focus, children/families audience
comparable_projects.comparison_notes: Discovery Center FAILED with Director of Development and no funding vs C.O. Polk SUCCEEDED with City Manager and appropriated SPLOST funds - demonstrates critical importance of decision maker type and funding status

public_presentation.strategic_value: Demonstrates comprehensive strategic planning methodology with personas, journey maps, evaluation framework - excellent process example even though project failed

ai_training_quality.notes: EXCELLENT training example - clear failure pattern with Director of Development lead, demonstrates importance of decision maker type and funding commitment

notes: Classic failure pattern: Director of Development leading (not ED/Board), donor 'contact' not actual commitment, no external pressure, no follow-up after expensive 86-page strategic plan delivered. Mark's lesson: 'Almost always difficult' when Development Director leads instead of ED/Board with authority. Project had EXCELLENT methodology (7 personas, empathy maps, journey maps, service blueprints, evaluation framework) but wrong decision maker doomed it from start. Budget was realistic ($1M over 6 years, appropriately phased) - problem was not budget but lack of funding commitment and wrong authority structure. Perfect negative example showing that comprehensive planning doesn't overcome structural problems with client authority and funding status.

project_name: Howard World Wildlife Museum (Robert Howard Museum)

client.name: Howard World Wildlife Museum / Robert Howard Museum

location.address: 74900 US Highway 111, Suite 120, Indian Wells, CA 92210

client.description: Robert Howard's private taxidermy collection - 10,000 pieces of taxidermy and weaponry spanning 6 decades. Nonprofit organization formed.

client_screening.screened_out_reason: CRITICAL RED FLAGS: (1) Private taxidermy collection with suspected illegal/endangered species specimens, (2) Family board structure = likely tax shelter, (3) Client refused educational curriculum integration requirement, (4) Legal liability too high, (5) Ethical concerns with specimen legality

tax_shelter_indicators.notes: 10,000 piece collection over 6 decades. Nonprofit formed but likely family controlled.

ethical_legal_issues.decline_reason: DEALBREAKERS: (1) Suspected illegal/endangered specimens create legal liability, (2) Client refused mandatory school curriculum integration, (3) Family board = tax shelter scheme, (4) Professional/ethical integrity conflict

documents.notes: Proposal letter and contract agreement - v3 indicates multiple revisions

scope.primary_deliverable: Master plan for private taxidermy museum

space_description.description: Museum designed around 7 continents showcasing 10,000 pieces of taxidermy and weaponry. Baobab tree entrance ('Tree of Life'), continental showcases, interactive exhibits.

budget_realism_check.notes: $110K for comprehensive master plan with 10,000 piece collection is realistic IF project were viable. Problem is legal/ethical issues, not budget.

project_financials.underbid_rationale: Standard discount offered, not strategic underbid
project_financials.notes: Budget: $156K original → $110K with discount. $200/hour rate (higher than typical $125). 610 hours planned. Project DECLINED due to legal/ethical concerns despite budget adequacy.

client_financial_profile.notes: Budget adequate. Problem is NOT money - problem is legal liability and ethical concerns with collection.

external_pressure.notes: No external forcing function, private vanity project

funding_status.notes: Collector has money but project not viable due to legal/ethical issues

educational_integration.notes: CRITICAL FAILURE POINT: Mark requires school curriculum integration for educational museum projects. Client REFUSED this requirement. Instant dealbreaker.

what_didnt_work: Private taxidermy collections almost ALWAYS have illegal/endangered specimens
When client refuses curriculum integration = instant decline (non-negotiable requirement)
Family board + private collection = tax shelter scheme
Legal liability from illegal specimens NOT worth any fee amount
10,000 pieces over 6 decades = high probability of illegal specimens
Museums 101 sent but client didn't acknowledge = warning sign
Weaponry collection adds additional legal complexity
would_do_differently: Screen out private taxidermy collectors earlier in process
Make curriculum integration requirement clear in first conversation
lessons_learned.replicable_model: NEGATIVE screening pattern: Private collector + Taxidermy + Family board + Refuses curriculum = DECLINE IMMEDIATELY
lessons_learned.template_value: Perfect example of when professional/ethical standards require project decline regardless of budget adequacy

follow_up_strategy.notes: Project declined due to legal/ethical concerns. No follow-up.

comparable_projects.similarity: Both involve collections/specimens, both declined for integrity reasons
comparable_projects.comparison_notes: Cabela declined for impossible positioning, Howard declined for legal liability

ai_training_quality.notes: EXCELLENT screening example: Shows when to decline despite adequate budget. Clear red flags: private collector + taxidermy + family board + refused curriculum = decline.

notes: Howard World Wildlife Museum - Robert Howard's 10,000 piece private taxidermy and weaponry collection spanning 6 decades. Nonprofit formed, located Indian Wells, CA (Riverside County). Proposal March 2024: $156K → $110K with discount, $200/hour rate. Museum concept: Baobab tree entrance (Tree of Life), 7 continents layout, interactive exhibits, STEM activities, school field trips. CLIENT REFUSED CURRICULUM INTEGRATION - instant dealbreaker. SUSPECTED ILLEGAL/ENDANGERED SPECIMENS in 10,000 piece collection = massive legal liability. Family board structure = likely tax shelter scheme. Museums 101 sent but not acknowledged. PROJECT DECLINED despite adequate budget ($110K) because: (1) Legal liability from suspected illegal specimens, (2) Client refused mandatory school curriculum integration requirement, (3) Family board indicates tax shelter not genuine museum, (4) Professional/ethical integrity conflict. LESSON: Private taxidermy collections + family boards + curriculum refusal = DECLINE IMMEDIATELY regardless of budget. V3 file indicates multiple proposal revisions before final decline. Perfect example of ethical screening - some projects are not worth the risk at any price.
